bioprojects.title: Clostridium sporogenes strain:NCIMB 10696 Genome sequencing

description.comment: Clostridium sporogenes is a gram positive, rod shaped, endospore-forming bacterium. An obligate anaerobe, it is widely used in the food and healthcare industry to test food preservation and disinfection procedures against clostridial spores. Strain NCIMB 10696 (Hall388 McClung2004) was isolated from soil and has potential as a delivery vehicle for treating solid tumours.

Clostridium taeniosporum strain:1/k Genome sequencing and assembly

description.comment: Clostridium taeniosporum is a spore-forming, anaerobic, non-pathogen which is unique. About twelve large, ribbon-like appendages are attached to one spore pole. The appendages are assembled from smaller complexes consisting of a spherical head and a long, thin tail. The spherical heads assemble in long parallel rows to form on surface of the appendages; the tails point away to form the other surface. The appendages are so large that about 50,000 small complexes are required to form each appendage. This organism has great potential in studies of developmental biology, structural biology, industrial uses (e.g., as a surface display host to express epitopes for vaccine use), in clostridial phylogeny and in environmental microbiology. Analysis of its genome will provide the basis for those studies.
description.title: Clostridium taeniosporum genomics

bioprojects.title: Clostridium formicaceticum strain:DSM 92 Genome sequencing and assembly

description.comment: Clostridium formicoaceticum DSM 92 was first isolated in 1970 from sewers and ditches around Goettingen, Germany. It is described as a Gram-negative, obligate anaerobic, mesophilic, motile, rod-shaped and spore-forming organism with homoacetate fermentation during the exponential growth phase and additional formate production in the stationary growth phase.
